request_pathways.name: Authorization to Obtain or Release PHI (Clinic)
Fax submission to Hendrick Service Center
Personal pickup at Hendrick Service Center

access_pathway.primary_pathway_description: Patient downloads a flat PDF authorization form, prints and fills it by hand, and submits via fax, mail, email, or in-person to the Hendrick Service Center.

red_flags: HIPAA misspelled as 'HIPPA' throughout both forms
Two separate forms required for hospital vs. clinic records with no cross-reference guidance
bright_spots: Email delivery option available on hospital form
Pre-populated Hendrick Service Center contact info on hospital form
Granular record type selection with 16+ specific checkboxes

findability.rationale: Level 4: Both forms are easily found via basic web search; the Medical Records page links directly to both PDFs with clear descriptions and stable URLs.

technical_accessibility.rationale: Level 3: The PDF has a text layer but zero fillable fields, requiring print-and-handwrite; fax and email submission are available as electronic submission options.

content_design.rationale: Level 3: Adequate single-page layout with logical flow and good record granularity, but dense legal paragraphs with small font, HIPAA misspelling, and no plain-language guidance.

patient_centeredness.rationale: Level 3: A patient can use the form by selecting 'Personal Use' and filling in their own name, but the form was designed for third-party release and provides no Right of Access language or patient-specific guidance.

compliance.rationale: Level 4: No notarization, witness, or in-person requirements; right to revoke clearly stated; minor issues include requesting last 4 SSN (unnecessary) and no fee disclosure or response timeline.

overall.summary: Hendrick Health provides easily findable but generic authorization forms that serve patient self-access as an afterthought; flat PDFs and lack of patient-specific design keep the experience functional but unexceptional.
